title: Justice Department Closes Investigation Over Eni’s Nigerian, Algerian Activities
text:
The U.S. Justice Department has closed its investigation into ENI SpA’s Nigerian and Algerian activities without finding any wrongdoing, the Italian oil-and-gas company said Tuesday.

Eni reiterated that “neither the company nor its management was involved in any alleged corrupt activities in relation to the OPL 245 transaction in Nigeria”.

The company, alongside Royal Dutch Shell PLC, has faced allegations of bribery around the acquisition of rights to the OPL 245 offshore oil block in Nigeria. The Justice Department was also looking into gas pipeline contracts that were awarded to Eni’s former subsidiary Saipem SpA in Algeria.

In 2017, an Italian judge ordered Eni and Shell to stand trial on corruption charges brought by public prosecutors in Milan stemming from the allegations around the Nigeria block.

“Eni is confident that the allegations currently put forward before the Court of Milan will be found to be groundless,” the company said Tuesday.

The company had voluntarily disclosed the allegations to the Justice Department and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, according to U.S. securities filings. An Eni spokesperson didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment. The SEC declined to comment.

In 2010, Eni and its former subsidiary, Snamprogetti Netherlands B.V. were the subject of dual Foreign Corrupt Practices Act settlements with the Justice Department and SEC.

Write to Olivia Bugault at olivia.bugault@dowjones.com and Dylan Tokar at dylan.tokar@wsj.com
description: The U.S. Department of Justice has closed its investigation into ENI SpA’s Nigerian and Algerian activities without finding any wrongdoing, the Italian oil-and-gas company said Tuesday.
